name: Chè Bắp
description: Chè Bắp is a Vietnamese dessert made with corn, sugar, and tapioca starch. It is a refreshing and sweet treat that is perfect for a hot day.

steps.step: Strip the corn until it's just the cob
Place four cups of water into a pot and place the cobs inside.
Boil the cobs for 10-15 mins
steps.note: This is to infuse the water with corn flavoring and scents

steps.step: Remove the cobs and put in the corn bits
Boil the corn bits for 10-15 mins
steps.note: This time may differ depending on the quality/freshness of the corn

steps.step: Add the cup of sugar and stir
Continue to add sugar to taste
Now make the tapioca starch mixture
Combine the tapioca starch into a cup of water to loosen/dissolve the starch
Pour the mixture into the pot and stir for 10-15 mins until the chè thickens
Once the chè clears up, it'll be done

name: Phở Bò
description: Phở Bò is a Vietnamese beef noodle soup with a clear broth, beef brisket, and rice noodles.

steps.step: Char the onions and ginger. Toast the spices until aromatic.
steps.note: Charring the aromatics adds depth to the broth.

steps.step: Quick boil the bones and beef brisket for 5 minutes to remove impurities. Rinse everything clean.
In a large pot, add bones, brisket, charred onion, ginger, and toasted spices. Cover with water (~3.5L).
Simmer for 3 hours, skimming scum off the surface as needed.
Remove brisket, set aside. Continue simmering bones 40 more minutes.
Strain the broth. Season with fish sauce, sugar, and salt.
Cook rice noodles according to package instructions.
To serve, add noodles to bowl, top with brisket slices and raw thinly-sliced beef tenderloin.
Ladle boiling hot broth over the beef to cook it.
steps.note: The heat of the broth cooks the beef.

steps.step: Garnish with beansprouts, basil, cilantro, lime, chili, hoisin, and sriracha as desired.

name: Chả Giò
description: Chả Giò are crispy Vietnamese egg rolls filled with pork, mushrooms, jícama, and noodles, wrapped in rice paper or wheat wrappers and deep-fried until golden. A classic appetizer or party food, they are served with lettuce, herbs, and nuoc cham dipping sauce.

ingredients.item: Egg roll wrappers (Menlo Brand or similar)

steps.step: Soak bean threads and wood ear mushrooms in hot water until soft (about 30 min)
Shred onion and jícama, squeeze excess moisture out
Chop noodles and mushrooms
Mix bean thread, mushrooms, onion, salt, pepper, sugar; add pork and jícama
Taste test mixture, adjust seasoning
Mix water and flour to make sealing paste
Wrap egg rolls, sealing the edge with paste
Fry at 325°F until golden brown and cooked inside (about 14 mins per batch)

name: Gỏi Cuốn
description: Gỏi Cuốn are refreshing Vietnamese spring rolls filled with pork, shrimp, rice noodles, lettuce, and fresh herbs all wrapped in rice paper. These light, healthy rolls are typically served with a savory peanut or nuoc cham dipping sauce.

steps.step: Poach pork belly with a pinch of salt until cooked through (about 30 min)
Slice the cooked pork belly thinly
Boil shrimp until just cooked (about 2 - 4 min)
Peel and halve the cooked shrimp lengthwise
Cook rice vermicelli noodles per package instructions (about 10 min)
Rinse, dry, and prep all vegetables and herbs
Set up a rolling station with all prepared ingredients
Dip one rice paper in warm water for a few seconds to soften
Layer noodles, lettuce, herbs, pork, and shrimp on the center of the wrapper
Roll the rice paper up tightly to enclose the filling
Repeat with remaining wrappers and ingredients

name: Bánh Bèo
description: Bánh Bèo are delicate steamed rice cakes originating from Huế, Vietnam. Each small, round cake is topped with mung bean paste, savory dried shrimp, crispy shallots, scallion oil, and served with a sweetened fish sauce.

steps.step: Soak mung beans overnight
Soak dried shrimp in warm water for 2 hours
Boil soaked mung beans in water until tender (about 30 minutes)
Mash the cooked mung beans into a thick paste
Drain and mince the shrimp finely
Lightly pan-fry the minced shrimp until aromatic
Mix rice flour, tapioca flour, salt, and water until smooth
Oil small bowls, pour 1 tablespoon of batter in each, steam until set (about 7 mins per batch)
Make scallion oil by heating oil and briefly frying green onions
Prepare dipping sauce by mixing fish sauce, water, lime juice, sugar, garlic, and chili
Top each rice cake with mung bean paste, shrimp, scallion oil, and crispy shallots

name: Bánh Xèo
description: Bánh Xèo are savory, crispy Vietnamese rice crepes flavored with coconut milk and turmeric, and filled with pork, shrimp, and bean sprouts. The name 'bánh xèo' refers to the sizzling sound these crepes make when batter hits the hot skillet. They are typically served with fresh herbs, lettuce, and a dipping sauce.

steps.step: Mix rice flour, cornstarch, turmeric powder, salt, coconut milk, water, and sliced green onions into a smooth batter
Let the batter rest for at least 30 minutes
Heat a nonstick skillet over medium-high and add a little oil
Add a few pork slices and shrimp, cook until pork is no longer pink and shrimp is just cooked
Pour in a thin layer of batter, swirl to coat the pan
Top with bean sprouts
Cover and cook until edges are crispy and bottom is golden (about 4 minutes)
Fold crepe in half and slide onto a plate
Repeat with remaining batter and fillings
Serve with lettuce, herbs, and dipping sauce

name: Bánh Chưng / Bánh Tét
description: Bánh Chưng (square), Bánh Tét (cylindrical), and Bánh Tổ (variation) are traditional Vietnamese sticky rice cakes made with glutinous rice, mung beans, and pork, wrapped in banana leaves and boiled or steamed. They are a central delicacy at Tết (Lunar New Year) celebrations.

steps.step: Soak glutinous rice and mung beans in water for several hours.
Season pork with fish sauce, salt, and pepper.
Drain soaked mung beans, steam them until soft, and mash.
Rinse and dry banana leaves, cut to size for wrapping.
Layer banana leaves, add rice, mung bean, pork, and more rice, fold and wrap tightly with twine.
Boil in a large pot of water (or steam) for about 6 hours (larger batches can take longer).
Remove, allow to cool, and slice to serve.

name: Bánh Đậu Xanh
description: Bánh Đậu Xanh is a Vietnamese steamed pandan cake, recognized for its beautiful green color and soft, chewy layers. Made with rice flour, tapioca starch, pandan extract, sugar, and coconut milk, it's a fragrant, lightly sweet treat often enjoyed as a snack or at celebrations.

steps.step: Mix rice flour, tapioca starch, sugar, salt, coconut milk, and pandan extract in a bowl until smooth
Lightly grease a cake pan with oil
Pour a thin layer of batter into the cake pan and steam until set (about 7 minutes)
Pour another layer of batter and steam until set (about 7 minutes)
Repeat until all batter is used, alternating colors if desired
Let cake cool completely before removing from pan and slicing

name: Bánh Cam
description: Bánh Cam are delicious Vietnamese fried sesame balls with a crispy golden shell and tender, chewy glutinous rice flour dough. The filling is sweet mung bean paste, and each ball is rolled in sesame seeds before deep frying.

steps.step: Soak mung beans for 1-2 hours
Boil mung beans until soft (about 30 minutes)
Mash cooked mung beans with coconut milk, sugar, and salt for the filling
Mix glutinous rice flour, sugar, baking powder, and water to make a smooth dough
Divide dough into small balls and flatten to wrap around a small amount of mung bean filling
Seal and roll each ball in sesame seeds to coat
Heat oil to 325°F (163°C) and deep fry the balls until golden brown (about 8-10 minutes per batch)
Drain on a rack or paper towels and cool before serving

name: Mì Hoành Thánh
description: Mì Hoành Thánh is a comforting noodle soup with springy egg noodles, delicate pork and shrimp wontons, and clear, fragrant broth. It is often served with leafy greens and sometimes slices of Chinese BBQ pork (xá xíu).

steps.step: Mix ground pork, chopped shrimp, green onions, soy sauce, sesame oil, white pepper, and salt to make wonton filling
Place a teaspoon of filling in each wonton wrapper and fold to seal
Bring a large pot of chicken or pork stock to a gentle boil
Drop wontons into stock and cook until they float (about 5 minutes)
Cook egg noodles per package instructions (about 6 minutes)
Blanch bok choy in boiling water until just tender (about 2 minutes)
Place noodles in serving bowls
Top with wontons, bok choy, and char siu pork if using
Ladle hot broth over, garnish with fried shallots and green onion, and serve

name: Thịt Nướng
description: Thịt Nướng features thinly sliced pork shoulder marinated in lemongrass, garlic, sugar, fish sauce, and other seasonings, then grilled or broiled to a caramelized finish. Commonly served with rice noodles (bún), herbs, pickled vegetables, or in a bánh mì sandwich.

steps.step: Mix garlic, shallots, lemongrass, sugar, fish sauce, soy sauce, honey, black pepper, and oil to make the marinade
Add sliced pork to the marinade and mix thoroughly
Marinate pork for at least 1 hour (or overnight)
Preheat grill or broiler to medium-high
Grill pork slices until caramelized and cooked through (about 3-5 minutes per side)
Serve with rice noodles, lettuce, herbs, pickled vegetables, and dipping sauce

name: Thịt Kho Trứng
description: Thịt Kho Trứng is a southern Vietnamese comfort dish of pork belly and eggs slowly braised in coconut water, fish sauce, and caramelized sugar. The meat becomes meltingly tender and the eggs soak up the rich, savory-sweet sauce.

steps.step: Boil eggs until hard (about 10 minutes), then peel
Make caramel by heating sugar in a pot until melted and deep amber
Add pork belly to the caramel and sear briefly
Add garlic, shallots, fish sauce, soy sauce, salt, and black pepper to the pork
Pour in coconut water until pork is just covered
Bring to a boil, then reduce heat, cover, and simmer for 60 minutes
Add the peeled eggs to the pot and continue to simmer uncovered for 30 minutes
Serve hot over steamed rice, with plenty of sauce

name: Hủ Tiếu
englishName: Vietnamese Pork and Seafood Noodle Soup
description: Hủ Tiếu is a savory, aromatic noodle soup from southern Vietnam, distinguished by its delicate clear pork broth, chewy rice noodles, sliced pork, shrimp or seafood, fried garlic, and crisp vegetables. It’s often served with fresh bean sprouts and lime.

steps.step: Blanch pork bones in boiling water for 5 minutes, then rinse
In a clean pot, add pork bones, dried squid/shrimp, daikon, and onion, cover with water and simmer for at least 90 minutes
Remove bones and vegetables from broth, season with fish sauce, sugar, salt
Boil pork shoulder slices in broth until just cooked (about 5 minutes), remove and set aside
Boil shrimp (or squid) in broth until pink (about 2 minutes), remove and set aside
Cook hủ tiếu noodles according to package instructions (about 5 minutes)
To serve, add noodles to bowls, top with pork, shrimp, bean sprouts, and herbs
Ladle hot broth over, finish with fried garlic oil and a squeeze of lime

name: Bánh Mì
description: Bánh Mì is Vietnam's beloved sandwich, featuring a crispy French baguette loaded with savory grilled or cold meats, pickled vegetables, cucumber, fresh cilantro, spicy chilis, and creamy mayonnaise. It’s the perfect fusion of French and Vietnamese flavors.

ingredients.item: Grilled pork, chicken, cold cuts, or tofu

steps.step: Slice baguettes in half lengthwise but not all the way through
Warm baguettes in the oven until crispy (about 5 minutes)
Spread pâté and mayonnaise evenly on both sides of each baguette
Layer in your choice of grilled meat, cold cuts, or tofu
Add pickled carrot and daikon, cucumber, cilantro, and sliced chili
Drizzle lightly with soy sauce or Maggi seasoning
Close the sandwich and serve immediately

name: Bún Bò Huế
description: Bún Bò Huế is a central Vietnamese noodle soup famous for its spicy, lemongrass-infused beef broth, thick rice vermicelli, sliced beef, pork hock, and pork blood cake (optional), all garnished with fresh herbs, lime, and chili.

steps.step: Blanch beef shank and pork hock in boiling water for 3 minutes, then rinse
In a clean pot, add beef, pork hocks, lemongrass, shallots, garlic, ginger, and fill with water to cover. Simmer for 90 minutes
Remove beef, pork hock and aromatics. Slice meat to desired thickness, return bones to pot
Season broth with fish sauce, salt, and rock sugar. Add shrimp paste if using
If using, add pork blood cake cubes and simmer for 10 minutes
Prepare bún noodles according to package instructions (about 10 minutes)
Optional: Prepare chili oil by frying chopped garlic and chili in oil until fragrant
To serve, add noodles to bowls, top with beef, pork hock, herbs, and banana blossom or cabbage
Ladle hot broth over, garnish with green onions, cilantro, basil, fresh chili, a squeeze of lime, and chili oil
